subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] The principles of my dictionary
msgSnippet: ... Just to clarify, CLOTH never has a unique sound of its own.  It s always merged with either LOT or THOUGHT or both. Historically, CLOTH formed when a group
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> Being an American speaker, I can't hear the CLOTH set at all, but this
> seems to make sense.

Just to clarify, CLOTH never has a unique sound of its own. It's always
merged with either LOT or THOUGHT or both.

Historically, CLOTH formed when a group of LOT words split off in pre-RP
and joined the THOUGHT set. This change was almost completely undone
in England by the end of the 20th century, but it had first spread
to America, which at about the same time was merging LOT and PALM.
When THOUGHT merged in the West with LOT = PALM, it naturally carried
CLOTH with it, merging all four sets.

--
John Cowan http://www.ccil.org/~cowan <cowan@...>
You tollerday donsk? N. You tolkatiff scowegian? Nn.
You spigotty anglease? Nnn. You phonio saxo? Nnnn.
Clear all so! `Tis a Jute.... (Finnegans Wake 16.5)
